title-group.article-title: Luciobarbus lydianus and L. kottelati, two synonyms of L. graecus (Teleostei: Cyprinidae)

sec.title: N/A
sec.p:
Luciobarbus lydianus
and
L. kottelati
, two synonyms of
L. graecus
(Teleostei: Cyprinidae )
JÖRG FREYHOF 1, * & BARAN YOĞURTÇUOĞLU 2
1 Museum für Naturkunde, Leibniz Institute for Evolution and Biodiversity Science, 10115 Berlin , Germany .

Ễ
joerg.freyhof@mfn.berlin ; https://orcid.org/ 0000-0002-7042-3127

2
Hacettepe University, Faculty of Science, Biology Department, Beytepe Campus, 06800 Ankara , Turkey .
Ễ yokbaran@gmail.com; https://orcid.org/0000-0001-8144-6191

* Corresponding author.
Ễ jfreyhof@yahoo.com

sec.title: Abstract
sec.p:
The Aegean
Luciobarbus graecus
,
L. lydianus
, and
L. kottelati
were described based on morphological characters. However, re-examination of fresh material from the three species revealed greater intraspecific variability in morphological character states, and wider overlaps in all postulated diagnostic traits than initially documented. Consequently, it is not possible to identify and distinguish these three species based solely on morphological characteristics. As they also share identical COI barcode sequences, these species are now considered conspecifics, and
L. lydianus
and
L. kottelati
are treated as junior synonyms of
L. graecus
. The distribution of
L. graecus
remains a biogeographical puzzle, and it cannot be excluded that this could be partly human-mediated. Population-level genomic studies, particularly those focusing on phylogeography and population genetics, may help clarify mechanisms underlying contemporary distribution of this species.

sec.title: N/A
sec.p:
Key words: Aegean basin
, COI , Freshwater fish , Morphology , Taxonomy ,
West Asia

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
In Greece ,
L. albanicus
is known from the Ionian Sea biogeographical region and
L. graecus
occurs in a small area of the Attikobeotia biogeographical region in the western Aegean basin (
).
revised the
Luciobarbus
populations of the Aegean basin and recognised three species,
L. graecus
in the western basin in Greece (Sperchios and Kifissos drainages),
L. lydianus
in the north-eastern basin in Anatolia , and
L. kottelati
in the south-eastern basin in Anatolia . No
Luciobarbus
has ever been described from the rivers of the northern Aegean Sea basin such as the Axios/Vardar, Strymon/Struma, Nestos/Mesta or Evros/Maritza. While
based their study entirely on morphological characters,
published COI sequence data of
L. albanicus
as well as
L. graecus
,
L. lydianus
and
L. kottelati
, and suggested that
L. albanicus
is well separated from the other three species, which have identical COI barcode haplotypes.

While
first published COI barcodes for
L. graecus , L. lydianus
and
L. kottelati
, raising the possibility that all three represent a ‘single species’ due to identical barcode regions,
had previously documented negligible cytochrome b sequence divergence between
L. graecus
(as
Barbus graecus
from Greece ) and
L. lydianus
populations (as
Barbus capito pectoralis
from Gediz) in Türkiye . Despite these previous genetic indications of close similarity, no subsequent effort has been made to comprehensively reevaluate the morphology, and assess the integrity of originally proposed diagnostic characters between these species, until the current study. We provide here, a formal re-evaluation of species boundaries in the light of genetic data. Towards this, we re-examine the morphological characters originally proposed as diagnostic by
using about the same numbers of fishes, but from slightly greater number of locations than
, so as to evaluate their ability to reliably distinguish between
L. graecus
,
L. lydianus
and
L. kottelati
.

sec.title: Material and Methods
sec.p:
After anaesthesia, fishes were fixed in 10% formaldehyde and stored in 70% ethanol, while fin clips for molecular analysis were directly fixed in 99% ethanol. Measurements were made with a dial caliper and recorded to 1 mm . All measurements were made point to point (never by projections). Counts (except lateral line scales) and measurements follow
. Serrae along posterior edge of last simple dorsal-fin ray were counted from Xrays. Lateral line scale count includes scales on caudal-fin base. Standard length (SL) is measured from the tip of the snout to the end of the hypural complex. The length of the caudal peduncle is measured from behind the base of the last anal-fin ray to the end of the hypural complex, at mid-height of the caudal-fin base. Vertebral counts were obtained from radiographs and include the four weberian vertebrae and the hypural complex. Gill rakers are counted on the outer side of the first gill arch including the anteriormost, wart-like rakers if these reach the lateral margin of the gill-arch. Map ( Fig. 1 ) was generated using the QGIS v. 3.30.2-’s-Hertogenbosch software (available at http://qgis.org). English language editing and proofreading of this manuscript is assisted by DeepL (https://www. deepl.com/write). Material examined in this study are listed at the end of the text. We examined eight individuals of
L. graecus
from one location (vs. four from a single location by
), 18 individuals of
L. lydianus
from four locations (vs. 22 from three locations by
, and 19 individuals of
L. kottelati
from three locations (vs. 21 from a single location by
.

Abbreviations used: SL, standard length; HL, lateral head length; FSJF, Fischsammlung J. Freyhof, Berlin , Germany ; ZFMK-ICH, Zoological Research Museum Alexander Koenig Ichthyology Collection, Bonn.

sec.title: Results
sec.p:
The molecular analysis, which included a total of 652 positions each for 15 nucleotide sequences in the final dataset, revealed all sequences from individuals initially identified as
L. graecus , L. lydianus ,
and
L. kottelati
to be completely identical. Hence, there is no recognisable evolutionary divergence between them in the COI sequence data.

distinguished
L. lydianus
(n=14) from
L. graecus
(n=4) by “…the lips fleshy (vs. thin), with the lower lip conspicuously thicker than the upper lip (vs. only slightly thicker), the middle of the lower lip with a median fleshy pad with a shallow groove posteriorly (vs. without median fleshy pad), and a well-developed black spot on each scale pocket back and the level below of the pectorals and pelvics, but not present on the scales on belly (vs. absent or inconspicuous).” We found no differences in lip thickness between the two species, and in both species, there are individuals with or without a median extension on the lower lip, a situation often found in other
Luciobarbus species
as well (e.g.
L. pectoralis Krupp 1985
). In both
L. lydianus
and
L. graecus
, each scale on the upper part of the flank is margined by a band of melanophores, forming a regular reticulated pattern. There is a black spot on the scale pocket (on the tissue reaching beyond the tip of the front scale) in some individuals, especially on scales on the middle of flank, but both the scale pocket pigmentation and pattern along the scale margins is variable, without any differences between the two species. Our material of
L. graecus
from clear-water habitats has a more contrasted pattern compared to our
L. lydianus
and
L. kottelati
from turbid waters.
further distinguished
L. lydianus
from
L. graecus
by several additional morphometric characters “…a shorter pectoral fin… (14.0–18.8% SL, mean 17.7, vs. 19.9–20.8, mean 20.4
[our material: 17–22 in
L. lydianus
vs. 18–21 in
L. graecus
]
), a wider head at anterior eye margin (39.7–43.5 % HL, mean 41.1, vs. 34.7–38.8, mean 37.4
[our material: 32–44 in
L. lydianus
vs. 36–41 in
L. graecus
]
), a shallower head (head depth at occiput 58.7–64.6 % HL, mean 62.1, vs. 67.3–71.4, mean 68.3
[our material: 63–69 in
L. lydianus
vs. 56–67 in
L. graecus
]
), and a wider interorbital distance (33.5–36.6 % HL, mean 34.9, vs. 31.6–33.0, mean 32.3
[our material: 33–40 in
L. lydianus
vs. 30–35 in
L. graecus
]
). None of these can be confirmed as diagnostic, and would allow identification of any one of these species. It should be noted that our material of
L. graecus
( 175–205 mm SL) consist of individuals mostly larger than those examined by
( 110–183 mm SL and some effect of allopatric growth cannot be fully excluded, but also not confirmed).

As none of the characters proposed as diagnostic for
L. lydianus
by
could be confirmed on our own material, and as there is no difference between the two species in their COI sequences, we treat
L. lydianus
as a synonym of
L. graecus
.

It should be noted that the type locality of
L. graecus
given by
include the Aspropotamos River ( Acheloos ) and lake of Wrachori [ Trichonis ] in Greece . Economidis & Herzig-Straschil (in Bănărescu & Bogutskaya , 2003: 220) have already clarified that this is an error and that the locality of the lectotype remains unknown, and is possibly situated in the Sperchios drainage. Indeed, this bears a certain risk of taxonomic instability. There could be two species of
Luciobarbus
in eastern Greece , the one identified here as
L. graecus
, and a second, to which the lectotype belongs. This speculative second species has not yet been discovered or may already be extinct. If this could be demonstrated,
L. lydianus
would be the available name for the widespread species discussed here. However, there is no indication that this scenario is realistic.

did not discuss the differences between
L. graecus
and
L. kottelati
, but only the differences between
L. lydianus
and
L. kottelati
.
distinguish
L. lydianus
from
L. kottelati
by “having the dorsal-fin origin directly above pelvic-fin origin or very slightly behind it (vs. conspicuously behind), the caudal-fin lobes of equal length (vs. lower lobe longer than upper).” In our material, there is no difference between the two species in either of the two characters. The dorsal-fin origin is considerably behind or above the pelvic-fin origin in only a few individuals of
L. kottelati
(see Fig. 7 ). In most individuals of
L. kottelati
, as well as in
L. lydianus ,
and
L. graecus ,
it is slightly behind the pelvic-fin origin, and only rarely is it above the pelvic-fin origin. This character is quite variable, but does not allow differentiation between
L. lydianus
and
L. kottelati
. Both caudal lobes are of equal length, or (usually) the lower caudal lobe is longer in both species.
provided additional diagnostic characters that distinguish
L. kottelati
from
L. lydianus
: “ … a greater predorsal distance (54.9–60.0% SL, vs. 52.0– 55.1 in
L. lydianus
[our material: 55–58 in
L. kottelati
vs. 52–58 in
L. lydianus
]
) and by having fewer serrae along posterior edge of last simple dorsal-fin ray (23–27, vs. 29–33
[our material: 15-25 in
L. kottelati
vs. 18-23 in
L. lydianus
]
). …. a well ossified last simple dorsal-fin ray in adults (vs. weakly ossified [our material without obvious differences] ), somewhat fewer scales in lateral line (43–46, vs. 45–48 [
our material: 44–46 in
L. kottelati
vs. 44–48 in
L. lydianus
]
), fewer gill rakers on the first gill arch (14–15, mode 15, vs. 15–17, mode 16
[our material: 13, 13, 15, 17 in
L. kottelati
vs. 13, 13, 14, 14 in
L. lydianus
]
), …. a deeper body (body depth at dorsal-fin origin 25.6–28.9 % SL, mean 27.4, vs. 22.7–26.7, mean 24.4
[our material: 26–28 in
L. kottelati
vs. 26–31 in
L.
lydianus ]
), a deeper caudal peduncle (caudal peduncle depth 11.4–12.6 % SL, mean 12.1, vs. 10.6–11.8, mean 11.4
[our material: 12–13 in both species]
), and a shallower head (head depth at occiput 63.0–68.3, mean 66.1 % HL vs. 58.7–64.6, mean 62.1
[our material: 65–68 in
L. kottelati
vs. 65–69 in
L. lydianus
]
).

Furthermore,
distinguish
L. kottelati
and
L. lydianus
by three osteological characters summarised in Table 2 and Table 3 . This osteological data of
largely overlaps, and there is a non-overlapping difference only in the position of the dorsal-fin origin: above vertebra 15 or in the space between vertebrae 14 and 15 in
L. kottelati
(vs. above vertebra 14 in
L. lydianus
). These osteological characters differ even greatly in our own material ( Table 2 ). We confirm the difference found by
as in our material, the position of the dorsal-fin origin is situated above the space between vertebrae 13 and 14 (n=3), vertebra 13 (n=1), vertebra 14 (n=1) in
L. kottelati
(vs. above space between vertebrae 15 and 16 (n=2), space 14 and 15 (n=1), vertebrae 15 (n=1) in
L. lydianus
). But the direction is opposite compared to the results presented by
. Also, the number of predorsal abdominal vertebrae ( 13 in
L. kottelati
vs. 14–15 in
L. lydianus
), and the anterior-most dorsal pterygiophore (inserted between vertebra 13 & 14 in
L. kottelati
vs. 10 & 11 or 11 & 12 in
L. lydianus
) were different between nominal species, a character found overlapping by
.

Our osteological data do not agree at all with the numbers presented by
.
seems to have used a method for counting the osteological characters different from ours, making direct comparative analysis of our dataset impossible. As
and ourselves have used different methods, at least the same characters should differ in the same direction (as more in
L. lydianus
vs. less in
L. kottelati
), or both teams should have found non-overlapping character states. This is not the case and calls for more research on osteological characters in these
Luciobarbus species.
The differences in vertebral counts should not be overstated, as only four individuals of
L. lydianus
and five of
L. kottelati
, each from a single population were radiographed by us. These characters might be more variable if a larger sample size, especially from different populations, is examined. Further studies are thus encouraged to explore the variability of vertebral counts in these
Luciobarbus
.

Our material of
L. kottelati
and
L. lydianus
largely overlaps in most character proposed to distinguish both species. This is particularly relevant given that the original description of
L. kottelati
by
was based on 20 individuals from a single locality. Our analysis, including 19 individuals of
L. kottelati
from three different sites, indicates a higher degree of variability and overlap of morphological characters. As there is also no considerable difference between
L. graecus
,
L. lydianus
, and
L. kottelati
in their COI barcode sequences, we treat
L. kottelati
also as a synonym of
L. graecus
. Naturally, it cannot be excluded that
report characters that ultimately are not diagnostic, and there is still the possibility that they and we may have overlooked other characters in our respective examinations that could potentially distinguish between the different populations. However, it should be noted that discovering any new diagnostic trait, if present, is beyond the scope of the current study.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p:
The
Luciobarbus
populations studied here exhibit an almost complete overlap of character states, which was surprising.As shown by
, all three population groups are very closely related by sharing identical COI sequences. This suggests a very recent contact and gene flow between populations currently distributed over a relatively large geographic range (see Fig. 1 ). Biogeographic scenarios such as the Miocene freshened Aegean Lake Egemar, as described by
, must be excluded as a migration pathway, as the Miocene is too long ago to allow identical COI sequences.
have already stated that
Luciobarbus
is absent from large parts of the European Aegean Sea basin. It is unclear why these fish are not found in the rivers of the northern Aegean, between the Greek and Anatolian parts of the distribution of
L. graecus
. Furthermore, no other native freshwater fish species are known to occur in the Sperchios and Beotian Kifissos drainages, as well as in the rivers of the Anatolian Aegean basin; but not in those of the northern Aegean. This is also true for the rivers of the Aegean biogeographical basin such as the Vardar, Strymon, Nestos, and Evros, which have their own fauna— with none of the native species shared with either the Sperchios and Beotian Kifissos, or western Anatolia . The fauna of Attikobeotia, the northern, and eastern Aegean rivers form three well-separated biogeographical units. The occurrence of
L. graecus
in Attikobeotia and Anatolia therefore remains a puzzle. This justifies speculations about the causes of this situation, and three possible explanations are considered here as plausible.

•
Luciobarbus graecus
had a wider distribution, including intermediate rivers of the northern Aegean , during glacial or pre-glacial times. This would explain why this species has disappeared from all intermediate rivers of the northern Aegean , and why no other fish species is shared between the Attikobeotia, as well as the northern and eastern Aegean . Indeed, only glacial cold-spills are a likely reason, why
L. graecus
, if it was ever present in the rivers of the northern Aegean , may have vanished from this region. The water in the northern Aegean rivers may have been too cold for
L. graecus
to survive the glacial times.

•
Luciobarbus graecus
used the Central Aegean island chains to cross the sea via the Cyclades plateau or the North Aegean island bridge. This suggests an invasion of Greece from Anatolia or vice versa .
showed potential pathways from Büyük Menderes to Samos, Ikaria, Mykonos, Tinos, Andros, and Evia or from Lesbos to Skiros, and Evia. Additional arguments derived from comparable phylogeographic patterns are also documented in some other Aegean fish like
Knipowitschia mermere
and
K. thessala
, reflecting Plio-Pleistocene dispersals that were likely shaped by glacial-interglacial cycles (Tougard et al. 2021). At the Last Glacial Maximum around 20,000 years ago, sea levels were much lower than present (
) and might have exposed land connections between some Aegean Islands facilitating faunal dispersal. However, dispersals between the landmasses would have required crossing a seaway in some capacity and
Luciobarbus species
are known to be able to enter brackish waters, at least in North Africa (Personal observations). The arguments about dispersal through the Central Aegean islands, or via intercontinental bridges remain as untested hypotheses. Current knowledge suggests that permanent freshwater streams and fish are mostly absent from these islands, except for Lesbos and Samos (
). Additionally, there is no paleontological evidence of past freshwater habitats or fish faunas on the Aegean islands. Currently, there is also no data on historic hydrology and fish assemblages in this region. Therefore, the assumptions underlying these biogeographical hypotheses remain unsupported.

• The current range of
L. graecus
may be the result of an early translocation. It is possible that
L. graecus
was a forerunner of carp (
Cyprinus carpio
) translocation and culture, before carp was widely available. For thousands of years, the Aegean Sea has been a region where ships have transported a wide range of goods from one coastal city to another.
Luciobarbus graecus
is a large, palatable species and there is no doubt, that it was consumed by humans. Therefore, it was potentially transported within, and outside its range.As the species is quite widespread in Anatolia , it is likely that Greek traders transported live fish from the east to the west coast of the Aegean, and potentially introducing it to parts of its range in Anatolia . This could potentially be tested by bones of
L. graecus
appearing at a historical starting point in time, particularly in sediments of lakes. In Greece , they may have been released or escaped from fish-keeping. It should also be noted, that recently
L . graecus
has been introduced to the artificial Lake Beletsi (Mt. Parnitha) and to Lake Marathon, and Kifissos River in Attica (
). Recent examples of introductions from Aegean islands to the mainland can demonstrate ongoing human-mediated dispersal potential (
).

Naturally, the present study does not have the scope to explore these speculations further. More research is therefore encouraged to test whether
L. graecus
is native to Greece , or represents an early introduction from Anatolia .

sec.title: Comparative material examined
sec.p:
Luciobarbus graecus
. ZFMK-ICH 50817-50822, 8, 175–205 mm SL;
Greece : Yliki lake east of Akraifnia , 38.4310 23.2440
.

Luciobarbus lydianus .
FSJF 1977, 4, 73–95 mm SL; Türkiye : İzmir prov. : Bakır at Karadere , 39.1006 27.4005
.—
FSJF 2340, 7, 81–194 mm SL; Türkiye : Çanakkale prov. : River Biga between Biga and Çan , 40.1725 27.2143
.—
FSJF 2350, 6, 88–195 mm SL; Türkiye : Çanakkale prov. : Bakacak at Bakacak , 40.2047 27.0867
.—
FSJF 2369, 1, 138 mm SL; Türkiye : Çanakkale prov. : Behramkale north of Assos , 39.4986 26.3333
.

Luciobarbus kottelati .
FSJF 1851, 1, 169 mm SL; Türkiye : Aydın prov. : Büyük Menderes south of Aydın at road to Muğla, 37.7832 27.8390
.—
FSJF 2336, 16, 62–101 mm SL; Türkiye : Aydın prov. : A tributary to stream Çine , west of Kahraman , 37.6002 28.0079
.—
FSJF 3710, 2, 86–124 mm SL; Türkiye : Aydın prov. : Akçay 10 km south of Nazilli , 37.8098 28.3152
.

sec.title: Acknowledgements
sec.p:
We are pleased to extend our gratitude to Nina Bogutskaya (Vienna) , who competently analysed x-ray pictures, Maurice Kottelat (Delémont) for allowing us to use his image of
L. graecus , Müfit Özuluğ
(Istanbul) for support during fieldwork, and Fabian Herder (Bonn) for allowing us to examine material under his care.
